column16:
Several comments:
1. LOINC has long been the accepted terminology system for document and section codes in HL7.  Requesting codes from LOINC for a specific purpose is not challenging.  I would prefer the document and section codes use LOINC so that we have fewer vocabularies to reference for document ontology.

PCDex seems to be missing a case of how this would be handled using existing technology, or a description of how the proposed solution would impact user workflows, or perhaps even a description of who those users are and what their current workflows are.  Again, it shows some variance from other Da Vinci specifications.
column17: Use LONIC codes where possible.

column16:
Not clear if/how provenance is represented in this FHIR Implementation Guide.  Provenance (who, what, when, where, why) is essential at:  1) point of origination (at the source, for newly captured content), 2) point of update (for newly updated content, preserving previous content and its provenance).

Who = subject of care/information (typically the patient)
Who = performer of action taken
Who = author of information captured or updated
Who = organization
What = action taken
When = date/time of action taken
When = date/time of information capture or update
Where = physical location of action taken
Where = physical location of information capture or update
Where = network address and/or device ID where information captured or updated
Why = rationale, purpose of action taken
Why = rationale, purpose of information capture or update

Granularity of provenance (e.g., binding authorship to content) may be at the dataset or element level.
column17: How is provenance represented?

column16: Text field does not require all the content in the human readable section-- need to consider what should be considered critical for human readable content.
column17: What should be considered critical for human readable content

column16: If authorization will not happen using a patient authorization using OAUTH then recommend IG reference a shared approach using communication request. Consider duplicating HREX or CDEX approaches. Clarify what requests and what responses are appropriate and how it is applied to the record. Please also clarify the LOINC code for the communication request and category.
column17: Recommend IG reference a shared approach for authorization using communication request.

column16: Need title fields to be clearer for users to implement consistently-- what is the document and section title to contain? Should it reference any patient or plan identifier?
column17: Need title fields to be clearer for users to implement consistently.

column16: Patient identifiers-- recommend reusing approahces from USCore, other DaVinci use cases. Need to address case where a plan ID may be missing. Consider whether SSN is an appropriate ID or additional source of ID. Work with payers on patient matching requirements.
column17: Recommend reusing patient identifier approach from US Core.

column16: Payers have indicated that in the currnet state there is a limited storage and access to data for members who are no longer enrolled in a plan. As a result, this use case may be limited by the duration of payer data retention. Could be addressed by CMS in their final rule but recommend that the IG suggest an approach that payers think is reasonable for records retention. Other legal requirements may apply.
column17: This use case may be limited by the duration of payer data retention.

column16: Are the FHIR Care Plan(s) expected to be reconciled? If so, who would perform that action? Should the IG be enhanced with a discussion of reconciled plans? If the plan was transmitted by a prior payer and reconciled but not altered, would any additional notation be appropriate other than typical provenance?
column17: Are the FHIR Care Plan(s) expected to be reconciled?

column16: Clarify what "active treatment" measns in the payer world and whether the presence of a FHIR Care Plan with an "active" status is all that is needed to indicate that. Are there instances where an "active" Care Plan would not actually contain active treatment? If so clarify how to use active status to reflect correct content.
column17: Clarify what "active treatment" means in the payer world.

column16: Clarify how a patient who was actively being seen but has no active treatments would be sent in a way that distinguishes a patient for whom the data wass found and no treatment was active from patients who were not found and patients who had no treatment plan information found.
column17: Clarify how no treatment information found is distinguished from patient with no active treatements.

column14: For this use case, we address the need for continuity of treatment when patients move from one payer’s health insurance plan to another. In the current situation, the patient and new payers often don’t have the information needed to continue treatment in progress or to determine that the therapies are necessary or medically appropriate
column15: Consider changing "therapies are necessary or medically appropriate", to "medically necessary".
column17: Consider changing "therapies are necessary or medically appropriate", to "medically necessary".

column14: This implementation guide defines standardized mechanisms for a patient or payer to enable a transfer of “current active treatments” with other relevant metadata and coverage-related information from a prior payer to a new payer.
column15: Consider clarifying or further defining, " other relevant metadata and coverage-related information"
column17: Consider clarifying or further defining, " other relevant metadata and coverage-related information"

column14: Optimally, the coverage decision exchange should allow relevant clinical information about decisions, treatments, and their context to align with the approach that clinicians and clinical systems take to describe this same content. This should and does include consideration of the Patient Care approach to longitudinal care planning and exchange and the regulatory framework of data exchange at transitions of care mandated by the Office of the National Coordinator for Health IT (ONC) and CMS.

column14: In many cases, the Coverage Transition document either won’t already exist or won’t be up-to-date and some degree of manual work will be required by payer staff to gather content, organize it and provide the appropriate document narrative. This may take hours or even a few days. The duration of the authorization token SHALL therefore take this into account and allow sufficient time that the authorized access will not expire prior to the document being delivered. (Allowance should also be made for a delay of 1-2 days in retrieval by the target system in the event of a plannned or unplanned system outage.)
column16: Isn’t the Token duration only a concern for authorizing sending the CommunicationRequest? What is the relevance for the Responding Payor sending the response?

column14: The US Core profiles impose terminology expectations that reflect commonly used clinical terminologies. These may not always align with commonly used billing codes. While billing codes may be sent as well (as additional translations), payers SHALL translate to the appropriate clinical terminology (e.g. SNOMED CT) in order to comply with the US Core profiles if an appropriate code exists in the US Core value set.
column16: This is a payor to payor not a payor to provider data exchange, so while payors may supply clinical terminologies if they receive data in clinical terminologies or are prepared to map, it should not be a requirement that payors transform materials received from authorative sources.
column17: It should not be a requirement that payors transform materials received from authorative sources.

column16: The Cdex CommunicationRequest confuses system-level communication with person-level communication. Further, it hampers interoperability by duplicating the intent and superior features of FHIR Messaging. It should be removed from this IG in favor the simple and widely implemented RESTful FHIR APIs.
column17: The CDex CommunicationRequest should be removed from this IG in favor the simple and widely implemented RESTful FHIR APIs.

column16: This justification for a document-based approach is refreshing and convincing. Why aren't we using the standard endpoints for interacting with FHIR Documents (https://www.hl7.org/fhir/documents.html#bundle). This IG should abandon the use of CommunicationRequest/Communication in favor of more standard and reasonable approaches.
column17: Why aren't we using the standard endpoints for interacting with FHIR Documents?

column14: While the eventual target of future versions of this IG may be to allow fully automated import and use of the provided payer data, it is likely that at least some cases will always require human review and, in the short term, most/all payers will incorporate human review in the consumption of the data shared. The document approach significantly simplifies this review process.
column16: Using the current state to justify why your future thing is limited, is a gamble. Assuming a future where import is fully automated and no human review is necessary -- what's the optimal integration pattern? Is it still pushing documents around asynchronously?
column17: Using the current state to justify why your future thing is limited, is a gamble.

column16: Overall, it would be a lot simpler and cheaper for the old payer to simply expose a RESTful API of mature FHIR resources, rather than creating this new document containing these resources.
column17: Overall, it would be a lot simpler and cheaper for the old payer to simply expose a RESTful API of mature FHIR resources, rather than creating this new document containing these resources.

column14: The CMS NPRM on interoperability published in the Federal Register on March 3, 2019, requires that providers enable members to exchange clinical information from a prior payer to the current payer for a period of 5 years after they leave a plan and move to another covered plan.
column16: The term provider here  should be switched to "payer".  This guide appears to be applying to health plans sharing information from one plan to the next, so a typical healthcare "provider" would not be involved.
column17: The term provider here  should be switched to "payer".

column14: Using the token, the new payer’s system requests a Coverage Transition document from the prior plan. The prior plan either locates an existing document (previously prepared) or assembles the information needed and creates the document
column16: This section should make clear that the plan should assemble the information needed using available info within their own system.  It is currently ambiguous as to how the plan will assemble the information used when creating a document. Plans should not reach out to providers to pull information unless explicitly directed by the patient.
column17: The plan should assemble the information needed using available info within their own system.

column14: (3) Communication (with doc) posted
column16: More clarity is needed around #3 with what “communication (with doc) posted” means.
column17: More clarity is needed around #3 with what “communication (with doc) posted” means.

column14: In the event that the member does not authorize exchanges of sensitive data, the prior plan SHALL have a method to sequester such information and make it unavailable for exchange. This SHOULD happen as part of the authorization process.
column15: In the event that the member does not authorize exchanges of sensitive data, the prior plan SHALL have a method to sequester such information and make it unavailable for exchange. This SHALL happen as part of the authorization process.
column16: In order to be effective, the sequestration option needs to happen at the time of authorizing the sharing.  If a plan is not sequestering data up front, what good does the sequestration serve?   In order to protect the patient's interest in sequestering data as they see appropriate, these aspects of sensitive data privacy control should be mandatory.
column17: In order to be effective, the sequestration option needs to happen at the time of authorizing the sharing.

column14: 4.	The new plan incorporates the information in the document into their utilization management/utilization review process for review and approval of the ongoing treatments for the new member.
column16: There needs to be requirements on the completeness of data exchanged from the old payer.   This sounds like it is going to involve some burdensome manual work for the old payer.  If the data is limited to the bare minimum in order to reduce burdens, it could lead to incompleteness of data received.
column17: There needs to be requirements on the completeness of data exchanged from the old payer.

column14: Target plans SHALL therefore allow the user to authenticate to multiple other payers to retrieve relevant data .
column16: The guide should explicitly state requirements that the patient needs to grant permission for each plan.
column17: The guide should explicitly state requirements that the patient needs to grant permission for each plan.

column14: AMA (Heather, Terry Cunningham)
column16: Neither Heather (McComas) nor I were on these calls and we should not be listed as authors
column17: Neither Heather (McComas) nor I were on these calls and we should not be listed as authors

column16: While it is a laudable goal to provide this use case a solution to continuity of care when switching between plans, it’s important to recognize that the payers are under no obligation to accept a previous payer’s determination of medical necessity or cover drugs/services/therapies in the same manner as the previous payer. The use case description should be very clear that this is about information exchange only and refrain from generalizing that such exchange will facilitate treatment continuity. A payer may receive information more quickly, but a human on the backend will still be making determinations about coverage.
column17: The use case description should be very clear that this is about information exchange only and refrain from generalizing that such exchange will facilitate treatment continuity.

column14: 4.    prescriptive on what information is required to substantiate medical necessity for any treatment;
column16: Absent some sort of rules on what would help a payer make coverage determinations, a payer is essentially free to request any data it wants in the name of “substantiating medical necessity.” There should be some way to limit or scope such requests.
column17: There should be some way to limit or scope requests for "medical necessity" data.

column14: 3.    guidelines that were used to evaluate the need for the care the patient is receiving,
column16: Payers are typically reticent to share these guidelines. Have they communicated a willingness to do so when using this IG?
column17: Payers are typically reticent to share these guidelines. Have they communicated a willingness to do so when using this IG?

column14: 1.    current care that a member is receiving,
column16: A member should have the ability to direct exchange of certain data (e.g., certain conditions, treatments, etc.). Shouldn’t be an all-or-nothing exchange.
column17: A member should have the ability to direct exchange of certain data

column14: The goal is to provide for continuity of care and to minimize provider burden. While the CMS NPRM points to the ability to exchange clinical data that is, at a minimum, defined by USCDI V1.0…
column16: The CMS rule requires payers to exchange the full USCDI at a minimum upon the beneficiary’s request. Does this IG aim to exchange information beyond the USCDI V1.0? We have concerns about whether excessive data access will lead to increased prior authorization and patient profiling—limiting coverage and access to care.  Appropriate details and relevant safeguards against misuse should be included.
column17: Does this IG aim to exchange information beyond the USCDI V1.0?

column14: 3.    guidelines that are used to decide that such a treatment is appropriate. These can include commercial guidelines such as MCG, InterQual and others. The goal is to include a reference (e.g. URL) to the appropriate guideline ;
column16: Are these guidelines able to be shared with the clinician, which would enable them tosend relevant information to support claims for the patient's coverage
column17: Are these guidelines able to be shared with the clinician?

column14: pre-reading
column16: In addition to the pre-reading provided here, there needs to be an implementation reference to a resource outlining what the requested data should not be used for (e.g., establishing barriers to coverage such as step therapy or prior authorization).
column17: There needs to be an implementation reference to a resource outlining what the requested data should not be used for

column14: By using the SMART on FHIR implementation of OAuth 2.0 and providing an appropriate access token  from a prior prayer plan to the new plan, the new plan’s application can authenticate to the prior plan and gain access to the specific member’s data.
column16: Is this a one-time authorization? Is it limited in scope based on the condition/treatment the member wants covered?  There should be consideration and clarification to ensure the patient controls their flow of information in such a manner
column17: Is this a one-time authorization?

column16: This section should make clear that the token expires once the relevant document/information has been retrieved/delivered.  The token should not grant unexpiring access, and the guide should be clear on the timeframe parameters.
column17: This section should make clear that the token expires once the relevant document/information has been retrieved/delivered.

column14: For example, conveying that a patient has had a double-mastectomy in the past. That may not be related to ‘active therapy’, but would still be relevant in terms of the new payer knowing not to send reminders for mammogram treatments.
column16: This is a slippery slope and leaves it to payers—rather than the patient—to determine what is important to a patient’s well-being. If the purpose of this IG is to address active treatments, the information exchange should be limited to those treatments only, absent a patient’s specific consent.
column17: This is a slippery slope and leaves it to payers—rather than the patient—to determine what is important to a patient’s well-being.
